<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 278, 170, 293]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 297, 329, 313]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Alternative to Practical  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 339, 415, 355]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 359, 366, 374]]<|/det|>
No Additional Materials are required.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 390, 386, 407]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 718, 432]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 432, 322, 446]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 446, 504, 461]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 460, 504, 475]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 475, 380, 490]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 500, 255, 515]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 526, 358, 542]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 541, 767, 557]]<|/det|>
You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 567, 604, 582]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 581, 759, 597]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 873, 89]]<|/det|>

In this experiment, both pendulum bobs have the same mass. A student suggests that since both pendulums have the same overall length \(D\) and mass, the periods \(T_{1}\) and \(T_{2}\) should be equal. State whether the results support this suggestion. Justify your answer by reference to the results.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
The period \(T\) of a pendulum can be determined by measuring the time \(t\) for 20 complete oscillations and then calculating the period. Some students are asked to explain the reason for this method being more accurate than measuring the time taken for a single oscillation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 134, 690, 152]]<|/det|>
Tick the box next to the sentence that gives the best explanation.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 155, 198, 280]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 163, 662, 181]]<|/det|>
The method eliminates errors from the measurements.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 195, 761, 213]]<|/det|>
The method is more accurate because the experiment is repeated.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 227, 789, 244]]<|/det|>
The method includes more readings so there is less chance for errors.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 258, 895, 275]]<|/det|>
The method reduces the effect of errors when starting and stopping the stopwatch.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 273, 920, 291]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 304, 144, 322]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 495, 92]]<|/det|>
A student is investigating the cooling of water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 146, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 918, 139]]<|/det|>
The thermometer in Fig. 2.1 shows room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) at the beginning of the experiment. Record \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 144, 841, 183]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 201, 532, 220]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 231, 920, 250]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} =\) .................................................... \(^\circ \mathrm{C}\) [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 262, 146, 280]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 262, 589, 281]]<|/det|>
The student pours \(50 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into a beaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 293, 568, 312]]<|/det|>
He measures the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{H}}\) of the hot water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 320, 771, 339]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{\mathrm{H}} =\) .................................................... $86^{\circ}\mathrm{C}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 355, 724, 374]]<|/det|>
He adds \(50 \text{cm}^3\) of cold water to the beaker. He stirs the water briefly.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 386, 690, 405]]<|/det|>
He measures the new temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{M}}\) of the water in the beaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 412, 771, 432]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{\mathrm{M}} =\) .................................................... $52^{\circ}\mathrm{C}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 448, 707, 467]]<|/det|>
Calculate the temperature fall \(\theta_{\mathrm{F}}\) using the equation \(\theta_{\mathrm{F}} = (\theta_{\mathrm{H}} - \theta_{\mathrm{M}})\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 477, 918, 497]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{\mathrm{F}} =\) ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 496, 920, 514]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 526, 144, 545]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 526, 861, 545]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 552, 918, 572]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{\mathrm{H}} =\) .................................................... $84^{\circ}\mathrm{C}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 592, 918, 612]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{\mathrm{M}} =\) .................................................... $54^{\circ}\mathrm{C}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 625, 707, 644]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 655, 920, 675]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{\mathrm{F}} =\) .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 688, 148, 707]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 688, 653, 707]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 752, 920, 770]]<|/det|>

<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 782, 920, 816]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 828, 754, 847]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 910, 920, 928]]<|/det|>
<form>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 918, 106]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 210, 141, 228]]<|/det|>
<label>(g)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 210, 918, 244]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 541, 91]]<|/det|> A student is determining the focal length \(f\) of a lens. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 410, 121]]<|/det|> Fig. 3.1 shows the apparatus used. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 128, 875, 247]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 265, 532, 284]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 295, 146, 314]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 295, 787, 314]]<|/det|> • The student places the screen about \(100\mathrm{cm}\) from the illuminated object. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 320, 175, 339]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 320, 920, 355]]<|/det|> She places the lens between the object and the screen so that the centre of the lens is at a distance \(u = 20.0 \text{cm}\) from the object. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 361, 171, 378]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 361, 920, 394]]<|/det|> She adjusts the position of the screen until a clearly focused image is formed on the screen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 400, 171, 420]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 400, 824, 420]]<|/det|> She measures the distance \(v\) between the centre of the lens and the screen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 426, 171, 444]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 426, 912, 444]]<|/det|> She repeats the procedure using values for \(u\) of \(22.0 \text{cm}, 25.0 \text{cm}, 30.0 \text{cm}\) and \(35.0 \text{cm}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 452, 175, 470]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 452, 500, 470]]<|/det|> The readings are shown in Table 3.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 482, 539, 500]]<|/det|> Table 3.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[351, 508, 645, 662]]<|/det|>

Every reasonable effort has been made by the publisher (UCLES) to trace copyright holders, but if any items requiring clearance have unwittingly been included, the publisher will be pleased to make amends at the earliest possible opportunity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 875, 918, 909]]<|/det|>
To avoid the issue of disclosure of answer-related information to candidates, all copyright acknowledgements are reproduced online in the Cambridge International Examinations Copyright Acknowledgements Booklet. This is produced for each series of examinations and is freely available to download at www.cie.org.uk after the live examination series.
